page.title: 02CHAUCER IN CHARTHAM
page.content: In May 1985 a spectacular village event took place to celebrate the sixth hundredth anniversary of Geoffrey Chaucer's 'Canterbury Tales'. Titled 'Chaucer in Chartham',it included a medieval feast in a marquee adorned with the coats of arms of many guilds and crafts.The feast included trenchers of bread and the traditional suckling pig.There was music played by minstrels,and roving players read from the Old English version of Chaucer,and the Wife of Bath sang a merry tune. Other festivities included a fair, where there were demonstrations of spinning and traditional pottery was on sale.There were also displays of various farm animals and a dancing bear.
